title: What song did U2 break through with in the 80s? - Quora

response.answer_text: I was hoping for some clarification about your question—namely, breakthrough where? The world is a big place and lots of countries have radio and sales hit charts! But since I’m not sure what you mean exactly, I’m going to provide a few different answers… For all of the following answers, I’m looking at both the Peak Chart Position of the single AND the Peak Chart Position of the accompanying album. After all, does a band really “break through” because of a stand alone hit single if the rest of the album tanks? Such a band would be considered a “one-hit wonder,” not a breakthrough mega-band. U2 Broke Through the UK in the 80s with “New Year’s Day” from War in 1983. That track was their first Top 10 hit in the UK, while the album hit #1 — U2’s first number 1 record in the world! While no other single off War cracked the Top 10 in the UK, the follow-up album also went to #1 and both singles (“Pride” and the title track, “The Unforgettable Fire”) charted higher than “New Year’s Day” (#3 and #6, respectively).U2 Broke Through in Ireland in the 80s with “With or Without You” from The Joshua Tree in 1987. This one is debatable because the fact is U2 had a #4 hit in the charts with a single from their sophomore album, October, way back in 1981; the single being “Fire.” And they had 5 more singles in the Top 10 between “Fire” and “With or Without You.” But their first 4 albums did not reflect the band having broken through: Boy = 13, October = 17, War = 16, The Unforgettable Fire = 53. Those numbers suggest that U2’s popularity was flagging from the get-go! But then The Joshua Tree dropped in 1987 at #1 on the Irish charts, and every U2 album since (except for the most recent, Songs of Innocence, which capped off maddeningly at #2) has topped the charts. On top of that, the three lead-off singles from The Joshua Tree (namely, “With or Without You,” “I Still Haven’t Found What I’m Looking For,” and “Where the Streets Have No Name”) all were #1 hits as well. So I think “With or Without You” demands to be recognized as U2’s breakthrough album in their own country.Finally, U2 Broke Through in America in the 80s with “With or Without You” as well. Compared to the UK and Ireland, U2’s first couple of albums barely made a blip on the US charts: Boy peaked at 63, and the follow-up which should have upped the band’s game fell flat and only managed 104. The first single from the band to show up at all in the US was 1983’s “New Year’s Day,” the same single which saw U2 become rock stars in the UK but which struggled to make #53 in the States. The next few singles performed even worse, until “Pride (In the Name of Love)” did a smidgen better by hitting #33. (SIDE NOTE: Bono’s lyric from “Hold Me, Thrill Me, Kiss Me, Kill Me,” includes a line that goes, “They want you to be Jesus, they go down on one knee, but they want their money back if you’re alive at 33!”) Not all too promising! Still, their albums War and The Unforgettable Fire did show some glimmers of hope as each came close to the Top 10 charts in the US. But could they actually break wide open, or were they going to have to settle for “Biggest Band in Europe?” The answer, of course, is history: The Joshua Tree landed at #1 in America, as did the first 2 singles off the record, kicking off with “With or Without You.” It’s easy to point to “With or Without You” and its iconic record as THE band’s breakthrough worldwide, but the whole story is certainly more complex than that. Aside from becoming big in the UK, another huge factor wasn’t a record or a single at all, but a nearly-calamitous live performance at the legendary fundraiser concert, Live Aid (Live Aid). Because of some questionable antics on the part of Bono, their 2-song set (which was supposed to have been a 3-song set) ended up making them stand out in front of a global audience and it probably earned them a million new fans and admirers overnight. Without “New Year’s Day” smashing the charts in the UK in 1983 and Bono rescuing and dancing with a girl in the audience at Live Aid in 1985, who knows if there ever would have been a Joshua Tree album or its massive hits? All is quiet,Ben(o)

“New Year’s Day” (1983) was their first song to reach the Top 10 in the UK. In the U.S. their singles didn’t get very high until 1987, when both “With or Without You” and “I Still Haven’t Found What I’m Looking For” both hit #1.
